regions.text:
Fig. 6 Visualisation of the methylation patterns of robust significant methylation features that were
consistently identified by Lycc. A visualisation of the methylation patterns of the 233 significant methylation
features consistently identified across all ten runs by Lgcc. Cluster labels were taken from the best run of Lege
as determined by log-rank P-value. Methylation is shown as a z-score. Scale was limited to — 3+ 3 using vmin
and vmax in the clustermap function in Seaborn to improve visualisation of differences between prognostic
clusters. The distribution of HCC grades between clusters appears to be relatively even

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Novel deep learning-based solution for identification of prognostic subgroups in liver cancer/crops_ordered/page_16/region_3_text.png
regions.text:
their strong predictive power for increased / reduced risks to HCC survival. By com-
parison, only 11—21 significant bottleneck features could be identified by the baseline
models following training. The Lesc latent space, when clustered, provided more insight-
ful patient groups than the baseline method [6]. Pipelines utilising survival informa-
tion, either to filter bottleneck features after network training (BCE, MSE) or directly
within the loss function (Lps, Lpysc) were able to separate patients in terms of survival
more significantly than the unsupervised Ly loss, as assessed using the log-rank test.
As expected, the clustering loss Lac produced quality clusters that had higher Silhouette
scores (best = 0.92) than the other loss functions. This was likely due to the high weight
of L; in the loss, meaning that the latent spaces produced were more complementary
to clustering. It was interesting to note that applying Lp, led to very distinct clusters in
terms of survival but it also gave good quality clusters in terms of the Silhouette score
(best = 0.77). However, the structure of the clusters obtained by Lyc and Lpg differed.
